Posts.Content: lisaAB wrote: I've stage !V metastatic BC mostly to bones. I've also been part of a dbl blind study for a little over 2yrs taking zometa/denosumab every 4 wks along with Femera, Lupron, Calcium & D.  I've developed jaw pain and I happen to be a musician/teacher soooo always playing winds/brass. A recent bone scan lit up my jaw and 2 new places on cervical spine. I was sent for CT of head & neck. The results were terrific the changes there were only athropic. I'm planning on talking with MD this wk, but curious if anyone developed similar problems.which became necrotic (sp?) or better put did your arthropathy develop into death of jawbone,,wondering if I'm more likely to have problems in the future with this due to mets to bone? lisaAB lisaAB Dx 2007, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Jaw Pain zometa/denosumab lisaAB lisaAB

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 04:47PM lisaAB wrote: Mari, How long a recovery from your hip surgery did you have?? lisaAB
Posts.Title: Stabilization interventions lisaAB lisaAB

Posts.Content: lisaAB wrote: I've received new of 3 thoracic spinal lesions and lesion in hip where it meets pelvis. I will be meeting with Ortho. MD..to find out about stabilizing these areas. Has anyone been through this and if so what procedures did you have?? What was the recovery time. I'm still working. Thank you for sharing your situations..here..soooo appreciated. Lisa B lisaAB Dx 2007, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stabilization interventions lisaAB lisaAB

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 12:25PM lisaAB wrote: Yes, my oncologist likes to be proactive..and suggests stabilization to avoid fracture and devasting paralysis (THoracic vertebrae including T12)..not sure what they will do with hip though?? I still hope someone responds with experience. Thanks for sharing, Lisa AB
Posts.Title: Stabilization interventions lisaAB lisaAB

Posts.Content: lisaAB wrote: Now that I am back in treatment with recurrent metastatic cancer, I want to see the doctor when I come in for test results. I like the NP, but I feel it is my right to have the "expert" present for my questions and to hear the results directly from the doctor. It is very important at this point in my cancer (stage 4) to have a relationship with my doctor. I actually went 2 full years without ever seeing the MD during followup to the initial treatments. That doctor is gone and I have a chance to actually be cared for as a person with a new doctor. I actually got angry when recently I had a scheduled appt. with followup to PET/CT scans with the doctor and at the visit was told I'd be once again seeing the NP..the hospital actually paged the MD who came to see me..how sad that this isn't standard practice though..and the patient as to be made to feel like a demanding pain to get time with the care provider the insurance/copay is paying for! Has anyone had these experiences too..what do you think? lisaAB Dx 2007, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I want to see the doctor for test results lisaAB badboob67

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 11:43AM lisaAB wrote: Deb: It's a miserable shame cancer centers don't have real support systems built in..ie. psychologists as part of the team to "patient centered care" that they all boast about. I find the stress of the scheduling of tests/appt./followup/billing/trying to stay employed all add to the already overwhelming anxiety...too bad we have to find yet another day of the week to see yet another professional in another location...and yet another doctor to prescribe anxiety meds.and followup..takes a lot of time away from an already shortened lifespan......arghhhhhhhhh. lisaAB
Posts.Title: 3 months sounds like forever.... AlaskaDeb lisaAB

Posts.Content: lisaAB wrote: Just curious about how long other folks wait when they've say a 10:30am chemo/infusion or injection in their perspective cancer ctrs. I usually wait 1-2hrs for the meds to come from pharmacy while in the chair.  Recently, I just come in for an injection of a study drug and lupron..have been waiting one & 1/2 hrs for just the meds to come to me. Is this unusual?? I get frustrated because I like to return to wk for at least a half day.  Eventually, I get docked for the time off when sick days are gone. Curious if this is typical?  Lisa B lisaAB Dx 2007, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Treatment Waiting Time lisaAB lovinmomma

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 11:12PM lisaAB wrote: I've been part of the study for denosumab in the first dbl blind study and now phase II..since 2007. I've done extremely well on this new drug..hardly any side effects aside from stiffness in AM which loosens up with a hot shower. I think both you and I are lucky to be able to get this new drug!! LisaAB
Posts.Title: Denosumab (Xgeva) vs Zometa Sweetanimo sfhusb

Posts.Content: lisaAB wrote: I'm a stage IV cancer patient with an average frame. I've been fighting for 10years now and feel quite fortunate. Recently, I was experiencing extreme fatigue for weeks and weight started coming off without my even trying..oncologist never really looked at full blood work and even kinda joked about my coming in to see her..ended up in the GP's office (more on top of me anyway) with a diagnosis of diabetes..now on more medication and watching diet...BMI is about a 20. Is there a corelation between all the years of cancer treatments and the onset of diabetes (I'm not an obese person)??  LisaAB lisaAB Dx 2007, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Diabetes lisaAB Mzmerz
